attributes.title: Perioperative Intravenous Lignocaine Infusion for Post-operative Pain Control in Patients undergoing Surgery of the Spine -Systematic Review and Meta-analysis

q1.value: Perioperative Intravenous Lignocaine Infusion for Post-operative Pain Control in Patients undergoing Surgery of the Spine -Systematic Review and Meta-analysis

q3.value: There is some evidence that systematic lignocaine positively influences perioperative pain management. Therefore we will evaluate the efficacy of lignocaine in perioperative spine pain.

q4.value:
Patients undergoing spinal surgery frequently suffer pain conditions including underlying and neuropathic pain, central sensitization phenomena and require significant therapeutic analgesia. Intravenous lignocaine is an amide local anaesthetic known for its analgesic, anti-hyperalgesic and anti-inflammatory properties. 
This review intends to summarise the evidence examining the efficacy and safety of perioperative intravenous lignocaine administration in patients undergoing spinal surgery.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This review intends to summarise the evidence examining the efficacy and safety of perioperative intravenous lignocaine administration in patients undergoing spinal surgery.
We will use a random-effects model to analyse data.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
•	Selection process
Two reviewers will independently screen titles and abstracts using an electronic screening form
(covidence web platform: http://www.COVIDENCE.org ). We will include articles for full-text review unless both reviewers deem them irrelevant. We will ensure that these studies are relevant to patient management in spinal surgery. The results of the data search will be presented in a PRISMA flow diagram indicating the number of studies retrieved, screened and excluded as per exclusion criteria. 
•	Data collection
Teams of two reviewers will perform data extraction using a pre-defined data collection form. Data will be extracted from each study based on pre-specified criteria (please see data items). Data extraction forms will be piloted initially on a small number of included studies. Subsequently, each of the included studies will be abstracted by two team members, independently, and potential conflicts will be resolved through discussion. Authors of primary publications will be contacted for data clarifications or missing outcome data, as necessary.

q13.value: We will be performing a search of all available studies. We will include all available studies which used intravenous lignocaine vs standard treatment or placebo in patients undergoing surgery of the spine.

question.value:
Primary outcome measures:
1. Pain score at rest (0-10 cm, 0-100 mm visual analogue scale (VAS), numeric rating scale (NRS)) at “early”, “intermediate” and “late” time points.
2. Adverse events (dichotomous outcomes: all-cause mortality, arrhythmias, other heart rate disorders or any sign of lidocaine toxicity)

	Secondary Outcome Measures
3. Intraoperative opioid consumption (remifentanil separated from other opiates due to unique short context sensitive half-life).
4. Postoperative opioid consumption, in “PACU ( post-anaesthesia care unit)” and “overall”, (in mg morphine equivalents ( MEQ).
5.Post-operative nausea and vomiting (PONV) at early time points (dichotomous in “post-anaesthesia care unit (PACU)” and “overall”);
6. Functional postoperative neuropsychological status scales ( eg. Quality of recovery (QoR) score or Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE));
7. Composite morbidity including pulmonary, cardiac and renal complication rates;
8. Surgical complication rates as defined ( dichotomous; postoperative infections, thromboembolism, wound breakdown at “early” , “intermediate” and “late time points”).
9. Hospital length of stay (measured in days).

Primary outcome measures:
1. Pain score at rest (0-10 cm, 0-100 mm visual analogue scale (VAS), numeric rating scale (NRS)) at “early”, “intermediate” and “late” time points.
2. Adverse events (dichotomous outcomes: all-cause mortality, arrhythmias, other heart rate disorders or any sign of lidocaine toxicity)

	Secondary Outcome Measures
3. Intraoperative opioid consumption (remifentanil separated from other opiates due to unique short context sensitive half-life).
4. Postoperative opioid consumption, in “PACU ( post-anaesthesia care unit)” and “overall”, (in mg morphine equivalents ( MEQ).
5.Post-operative nausea and vomiting (PONV) at early time points (dichotomous in “post-anaesthesia care unit (PACU)” and “overall”);
6. Functional postoperative neuropsychological status scales ( eg. Quality of recovery (QoR) score or Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE));
7. Composite morbidity including pulmonary, cardiac and renal complication rates;
8. Surgical complication rates as defined ( dichotomous; postoperative infections, thromboembolism, wound breakdown at “early” , “intermediate” and “late time points”).
9. Hospital length of stay (measured in days).

Synthesis- Criteria under which study data will be quantitatively synthesized
We will assess whether studies are sufficiently homogenous in order to combine and assess the results based on a number of clinically relevant parameters: commencement, timing, dosage and administration of intravenous lignocaine. We will assess the ability to combine the data based on clinical judgement.

We will report statistical heterogeneity using the Chi2 statistic and the I2 statistic. Both will be calculated for each of the outcomes listed above for the comparison with control intervention. Statistical heterogeneity will be declared if the Chi2 statistic has P < 0.1. Substantial or greater heterogeneity will be declared if the I2
statistic exceeds 50%.

If significant unexplained heterogeneity exists, or if there is an insufficient number of RCT’s for meta-analysis, we will describe data qualitatively.

Measures of treatment effect
For dichotomous outcomes, we will obtain a risk ratio (RR) from the intervention and control group event rates. For continuous data, we will obtain the mean difference (MD) from the difference between the intervention and control group mean values with associated standard deviations (SDs) if all studies measured data on the same scale.  The standardized mean difference (SMD) will be used when the studies all assessed the same outcome but used variable measurement tools. For example, the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) may be measured on a scale of 0-10 cm or 0-100 mm. We will perform the back transformation of SMD values into absolute values on a scale of 0-10 cm (VAS) in order to assist with the clinical interpretation. 

All opioid quantities will be transformed into intravenous morphine equivalents (MEQ, mg) as described in the Defined Daily Dose index (36).

q1.value: Systematic Review: Trials of Interventions for Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM) prevention and treatment

q2.value: Aoife Egan, delia bogdanet, Fidelma Dunne, Linda Biesty, Caroline Crowther, Eugene Dempsey, Shakila Thangaratinam, Declan Devane, Narjes Fhelelboom

q3.value:
GDM is a common metabolic disorder of pregnancy associated with adverse materno-fetal outcomes. Due to the high prevalence of GDM, there are multiple trials evaluating interventions for GDM prevention and treatment. Unfortunately there is wide variation in the outcomes that these studies collect and report. This makes evidence synthesis difficult. 
This systematic review forms the first part of a larger study to develop a core outcome set for studies of GDM prevention and treatment.

q4.value: The aim of this systematic review is to identify outcomes previously reported in trials of GDM prevention and treatment.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The following databases will be searched for relevant studies: MEDLINE, Embase, Web of Science, Cochrane Library and CINAHL. Key terms used to guide the search will include ‘GDM’, ‘gestational diabetes’, ‘maternal diabetes’, ‘hyperglycemia’, ‘pregnancy’, ‘prevention’ and ‘treatment’, combined as appropriate using the Boolean operands ‘AND’ and ‘OR’.
A full copy of the protocol is available at:  https://bmjopen.bmj.com/content/9/11/e030574.full

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

q11.value: This is a systematic review and will not involve the creation of any new data.

question.value:
The following data will be extracted from each study: study design, author details, year and journal of publication, targeted condition, criteria for diagnosis of GDM, interventions under investigation and all outcomes as reported in the trial (including definitions, tools for measurement, thresholds and time points).

Two review authors will extract outcomes independently and compare and agree on the outcomes extracted. Disagreement will be resolved through discussion with a third reviewer.
As outlined in the protocol, all outcomes reported in the included studies will be extracted.
The aim of this systematic review is to make a list of previously reported outcomes only. It will not involve any data analysis.

q25.value:

https://bmjopen.bmj.com/content/9/11/e030574.full

attributes.title: prereg
attributes.description:
Alcohol use disorders (AUD) are highly prevalent and debilitating, and standard treatment rates are poor. Cognitive biases, such as difficulty in ignoring cues in the environment that signal the availability of alcohol, have been shown to contribute to relapse in AUD. In recent years, cognitive bias modification (CBM) protocols have been developed in order to re-train and reduce these cognitive biases towards alcohol. These protocols involve simple computer tasks where participants are repeatedly trained to turn their attention (or responding) away from alcohol and towards non-alcohol related drinks. A number of studies have demonstrated that offering CBM alongside treatment as usual (approximately 4-6 sessions over the course of two weeks) can reduce the rate of relapse one year later, relative to patients in an active control group. Although promising, the effect sizes are small and there is scope to improve the current CBM protocols. 

The innovation of the current project is to modify current CBM protocols by introducing a financial incentive to perform well on the CBM tasks. This financial incentive provides an additional motivational route to control attention and inhibit responding directed towards alcohol. In this treatment context, harmful alcohol usage could potentially be reduced even further. To this end a pilot study will be conducted among alcohol-dependent outpatients to compare the preliminary efficacy of revised protocols for CBM in reducing rate of relapse, compared to an active control.  In addition, all treatment providers will be interviewed in regards to implementation issues and future strategies that could improve delivery of CBM in the clinical context.

This project involves an active network of researchers and clinical-facing experts, paving the way for future projects than can improve treatment outcomes for adults living with mental health issues (including AUD). This study protocol pertains to inpatients recruited from Jarrah House in the first instance (with the potential addition of other sites) and is closely related to an existing protocol for a parallel study with outpatients. This project is well-supported by collaborative partners (clinical and research experts both national and international) and has the potential to deliver significant health outcomes and opportunities for future development and roll-out.

q1.value: Cognitive bias modification for enhancing treatment efficacy in alcohol use disorder: pilot study of an adapted protocol aimed at reducing compulsive alcohol use in treatment seekers.

q3.value:
Specific Aims
1.	To determine whether abstinent patients receiving treatment for alcohol use disorder,  who receive six sessions of active CBM (attentional bias retraining or response inhibition training) show reduced rates of relapse (anything other than continuous abstinence, self-report) at 3 months follow up than those in a control condition who perform a working-memory task (active control condition).
2.	To determine whether change in scores on a well-validated measure of compulsive alcohol use from baseline to 3-months post intervention differs for those in the active CBM groups versus the active control condition.
3. To determine whether baseline scores on behavioural tasks measuring attentional bias for reward will be correlated with AUDIT scores.
4.	Secondary objectives: the pilot study will provide important information as to the feasibility of upscaling CBM across clinical groups within NSW. All treatment providers will be interviewed in regards to implementation issues and future strategies that could improve delivery of CBM in the clinical context.

q4.value:
1. If attentional bias retraining and/or response inhibition training reduce relapse rates in those intending to remain abstinent from alcohol then relapse rates (based on self-report, anything other than continuous abstinence) after 3 months (binary measure: yes/no) should be significantly less in these groups compared to the active control group.
2.  If attentional bias retraining and/or response inhibition training reduce compulsive alcohol cravings and cognitions in treatment-seeing participants than scores on the Obsessive Compulsive Drinking Scale (OCDS) should be significantly reduced in those assigned to these groups, compared to the active control group, at 3-month follow up.
3. Attentional bias for reward cues at baseline, alongside intervention group, will predict alcohol use and OCDS  craving scores at 3 month-follow up. 
3. Baseline scores on behavioural tasks measuring attentional bias for reward will be correlated (positively) with AUDIT scores.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: Participants and clinicians will remain blind as to the randomisation of participants to conditions.

question.value: This is an intervention study where the efficacy of two CBM protocols (attentional bias retraining and response inhibition training) are compared to an active control condition (working memory task).

q9.value: At each treatment facility, participants will be randomly assigned (sequentially) to the attentional bias retraining, response inhibition retraining and working memory (active control) group (n = 46 per group).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Inclusion Criteria:
Inclusion criteria will be a primary diagnosis of AUD and referral from clinicians. Exclusion criteria will be non-native speakers of English, diagnosis of Korsakoff syndrome, serious neurological problems including repeated seizures, learning difficulties, history of schizophrenia, strong withdrawal symptoms and visual or motor handicaps. Clinicians will assess inclusion/exclusion criteria and only those who meet criteria will be informed about the study. At the baseline session, we have also included questions on the aforementioned inclusion/exclusion criteria in the demographic questionnaire.

Proposed intervention:

1.	Information and informed consent: Individuals seeking treatment at various inpatient and outpatient faculties in NSW with a primary diagnosis of alcohol use disorder who meet inclusion criteria for the study will be informed of the study within the first three weeks of intake by a Research Psychologist/Research Assistant who is independent of their clinical care and, if interested, will be provided with information about the study. After 24 hours, if they are interested in participating, they can make an appointment with the researcher who will answer any questions. Informed consent will be obtained. Clinicians will remain blind as to the randomisation of participants. 

2.	Baseline Session: During the baseline session (1 hour long), participants will perform a general attentional bias task (15 minutes; see details below), the assessment versions of the alcohol attentional bias and alcohol response inhibition tasks (10 minutes each; see details below), as well as various self-report measures: 1. Demographic questionnaire, 2. Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test (AUDIT), 3. Severity of Alcohol Dependence Questionnaire (SADQ) 4. Obsessive Compulsive Drinking Scale (OCDS). 5. Beck Depression Inventory II (BDI). All questionnaires are attached. The baseline session will take place in a quiet room, using a laptop. Dr Poppy Watson will conduct the baseline sessions with the assistance of a research assistant and honours student (yet to be recruited and trained by Dr Poppy Watson). The experimenter will pencil in the appointments for the next six retraining sessions although flexibility will be maintained such that clients can complete the sessions at times convenient to them. Participants will receive $20 cash at the end of the baseline session as reimbursement for their time.

4.	Six x CBM retraining sessions: Over the course of 2 weeks, participants will return to the clinic (or UNSW) to complete six sessions (max. 20 minutes each) in which they complete either the alcohol attentional bias retraining task, the alcohol response inhibition task, or the working memory task (depending on the intervention group they have been assigned to). Sessions will take place in a quiet room, using a laptop. Dr Poppy Watson will conduct the retraining sessions with the assistance of a research assistant and honours student (yet to be recruited). The research assistant and student will be trained by the lead investigator (Dr Poppy Watson). Participants will receive $10 cash at the end of each session as reimbursement for their time. Treatment as usual will continue.

5.	3-month follow up: 3 months after completion of the training sessions all patients will be contacted via email and asked to complete a short questionnaire (online) assessing their alcohol use. They will also be asked to complete the OCDS questionnaire. Those who do not respond will be contacted via telephone and asked to complete the questionnaires over the phone by a researcher who is naive as to the purpose of the questionnaires (i.e. the fact that they are outcome measures following a CBM intervention). All questionnaires are attached. Upon completion of the questionnaire, the bonus payments (performance-contingent reward earned during the course of the study for all participants regardless of the condition they are assigned to) will be released to participants in the form of Woolworths or Coles vouchers. 

6.	Follow-up with clinicians: Clinic staff and clinicians who have provided treatment-as-usual alongside the CBM intervention study will be asked to indicate their views on how disruptive the study was to business as usual and suggestions for improvements in future implementation.

q13.value:
Sample size calculation: A sensitivity analysis (G-power) suggests that for the critical comparisons of relapse rates, alcohol use and questionnaire scores between the retraining and control groups, final group sizes of 40 (assuming attrition rate of 15%) would give 80% power to detect effect sizes of 0.32 at p<0.05. 

Baseline scores on behavioural tasks will be correlated with AUDIT scores to assess whether those scoring higher on hazardous alcohol use also demonstrate increased bias scores on these tasks. A sensitivity analysis (G-power) suggests that for correlational analyses 120 participants would give 80% power to detect an effect size of 0.22 at p<0.05.

q14.value: All attempts will be made to recruit 120 participants as per the power analysis. However, the project must be completed by mid-2021.

q15.value: We will continue to recruit participants until either 120 participants have been recruited or we reach June 2021.

question.value:
Over the course of 2 weeks, alongside treatment-as-usual, participants will complete six sessions (max. 20 minutes each) in which they complete either the alcohol attentional bias retraining task, the alcohol response inhibition task, or the working memory task (depending on the intervention group they have been assigned to). 

•	Alcohol Attentional Bias Task: We will use a commonly-used attentional bias task during both the baseline and retraining sessions (the dot-probe task). On each trial participants will see two images appear on either side of a computer screen – one soft drink and one alcohol image. After 500ms the pictures disappear and a small square (the target) will appear at one of the picture locations. Participants must respond to the location of the target (left or right) by pushing the appropriate arrow-key on a computer keyboard. The dependent variable is the time taken to identify the probe location. In the assessment version of this task, the target appears equally often at the location of the alcohol or soft drink image: an ‘alcohol attentional bias’ (AAB) is observed if participants are faster to respond when the target appears in the location of the alcohol picture (with a greater difference in response time indicating a greater bias). AAB score will be assessed in this way at baseline. In the re-training version of the task (used in the six treatment sessions), the target will always appear at the location of the soft drink image. In this way, participants are repeatedly trained to shift their attention away from the alcohol image and instead look at the soft drink. They will receive points for fast/accurate responses - later translated into a financial bonus (totalling between $30 and $50 overall – around $5-$8 per session) - providing additional motivation to attend to the soft-drink image rather than the alcohol image. 

•	Alcohol Response Inhibition Task: We will use a commonly-used response inhibition task (the alcohol go/no go task) during both the baseline and retraining sessions. On each trial, participants will see an image (either a soft drink or an alcohol image) appear on a computer screen. An overlaid letter will indicate whether participants should push the spacebar as quickly as possible (‘F’, 2/3 of trials) or whether they should not push any keys (‘P’, the stop signal: 1/3 of trials). The dependent variable is the proportion of stop trials where the participant is unable to inhibit their response. In the assessment version of the task, the ability to inhibit responses will be compared when the stop signal appears on the alcohol relative to the soft drink image (measured at baseline). In the re-training version of this task (used in the six treatment sessions), the stop signal will always appear on an alcohol image. In this way, participants are repeatedly trained to inhibit responding directed towards alcohol. They will also receive points for responding quickly (but stopping accurately), which will later be translated into a financial bonus (totalling between $30 and $50 overall). 

•	Active control: Working Memory Task: Participants will compete a simple working memory training task (N-back task). During this task, participants are presented with a series of alcohol and soft-drink images. In the simplest form, their task is to indicate (with a key press) if the same image is presented sequentially (1-back). Once participants have mastered 1-back (two consecutive blocks with 95% accuracy), the task is made harder by moving up a level to 2-back. Here participants must indicate whether the image on the screen is the same as that presented two images ago. This task can be made gradually harder (3-back, 4-back etc.) as accuracy improves. Participants will earn points for fast and accurate responses which will later be translated into a financial bonus (totalling between $30 and $50 overall).

Baseline Variables:

1. General Attentional Bias Task: We will use a visual search task, commonly used in our lab, to investigate distraction by general (non-alcohol-related) reward stimuli in this clinical population (baseline session only). In this task participants are instructed to find and respond to a diamond shape (the target) among a set of circles as quickly as possible, by pressing ‘C’ (horizontal) or ‘M’ (vertical). The faster participants make a correct response, the more points (and money) they earn. One of the circles in the display (the distractor) may be coloured either blue or orange (all other shapes are grey). The colour of this distractor circle indicates whether the current trial is a high- or low-reward trial. On trials with a low-reward distractor, correct responses earn 1 point for every 10 ms that respone time (RT) is below 1000 ms (e.g., an RT of 650 ms would earn 35 points). Trials with a high-reward distractor are labelled as “bonus trials”, and points are multiplied by 10 (e.g., RT of 650 ms would earn 350 points). The value-modulated attentional capture (VMAC) score is the response time to correctly identify the target when the display contains a high-reward distractor relative to when it contains a low-reward distractor.

2. Alcohol attentional bias score (see details above; RT to identify the probe on alcohol congruent relative to alcohol incongruent trials).

3. Response inhibition score (see details above; number of failed inhibitions to the stop signal on alcohol stop relative to soft-drink stop trials).
 
4. Demographic questionnaire (see attachment).
5. Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test (AUDIT). The 10-item AUDIT focuses on the negative personal outcomes attributable to alcohol use. This is the most widely used screening tool to assess hazardous and risky alcohol use behaviour with good test-retest reliability and internal validity.
6. Severity of Alcohol Dependence Questionnaire (SADQ). The 20-item SADQ captures the severity of the dependence (specifically the physical and affective symptoms of withdrawal). The measure has good construct validity and high test-retest reliability.
7. Obsessive Compulsive Drinking Scale (OCDS). This 14-item OCDS measure obsessive thoughts about alcohol use and compulsive behaviours toward drinking. The OCDS has good internal consistency and is predictive of future drinking . 
8. Beck Depression Inventory II (BDI). The BDI has proved internally consistent and acceptably reliable over an extended test-retest period.

3-month follow up variables (see attachment): 
•	Follow-up questionnaire assessing alcohol use.
•	OCDS (as above).

Baseline data: simple correlational analyses will investigate whether attentional bias scores at baseline correlate to AUDIT and OCDS scores.

All analyses described below will be conducted following both intention-to-treat (ITT) and per-protocol (PP) principles. The ITT analyses will include all randomised patients, regardless of the number of sessions that were actually completed or the length of treatment. The PP analyses will only include those participants who completed the study without any major protocol deviations. 

Manipulation checks: One-way ANOVA and X2 tests will be used (as appropriate) to examine whether the groups differ on demographic and alcohol use characteristics at baseline including age, gender ratio, treatment facility ratio, AUDIT score, SADQ score, OCDS score, BDI score. Where groups differ, these variables will be included as regressors in multilevel regression models (see details below).

For those participants who indicate an intention to remain abstinent, initial analyses will use X2 tests to examine whether there is a difference between the three groups in relapse (based on self-report, anything other than continuous abstinence) after 3 months (binary measure: yes/no).

A multilevel binary-logistic regression model will be used to examine relapse rates as a function of intervention group. Participants will be nested within treatment-facility (second level). First level regressors will include AUDIT score, attentional bias for reward at baseline and age (plus another other measures where groups significantly differ, see above).

Repeated-measures ANOVA with time (pre/post intervention) and group (attentional bias retraining/response inhibition training/active control) will be used to examine OCDS craving scores. Any interactions will be followed up with appropriate t-tests.

A multilevel regression model will be used to examine change in OCDS score (pre-post) as a function of intervention group. Participants will be nested within treatment-facility (second level). First level regressors will include AUDIT score, attentional bias for reward at baseline and age (plus another other measures where groups significantly differ, see above).

registration_responses.q1: Cognitive bias modification for enhancing treatment efficacy in alcohol use disorder: pilot study of an adapted protocol aimed at reducing compulsive alcohol use in treatment seekers.
registration_responses.q3:
Specific Aims
1.	To determine whether abstinent patients receiving treatment for alcohol use disorder,  who receive six sessions of active CBM (attentional bias retraining or response inhibition training) show reduced rates of relapse (anything other than continuous abstinence, self-report) at 3 months follow up than those in a control condition who perform a working-memory task (active control condition).
2.	To determine whether change in scores on a well-validated measure of compulsive alcohol use from baseline to 3-months post intervention differs for those in the active CBM groups versus the active control condition.
3. To determine whether baseline scores on behavioural tasks measuring attentional bias for reward will be correlated with AUDIT scores.
4.	Secondary objectives: the pilot study will provide important information as to the feasibility of upscaling CBM across clinical groups within NSW. All treatment providers will be interviewed in regards to implementation issues and future strategies that could improve delivery of CBM in the clinical context.
registration_responses.q4:
1. If attentional bias retraining and/or response inhibition training reduce relapse rates in those intending to remain abstinent from alcohol then relapse rates (based on self-report, anything other than continuous abstinence) after 3 months (binary measure: yes/no) should be significantly less in these groups compared to the active control group.
2.  If attentional bias retraining and/or response inhibition training reduce compulsive alcohol cravings and cognitions in treatment-seeing participants than scores on the Obsessive Compulsive Drinking Scale (OCDS) should be significantly reduced in those assigned to these groups, compared to the active control group, at 3-month follow up.
3. Attentional bias for reward cues at baseline, alongside intervention group, will predict alcohol use and OCDS  craving scores at 3 month-follow up. 
3. Baseline scores on behavioural tasks measuring attentional bias for reward will be correlated (positively) with AUDIT scores.

Baseline scores on behavioural tasks will be correlated with AUDIT scores to assess whether those scoring higher on hazardous alcohol use also demonstrate increased bias scores on these tasks. A sensitivity analysis (G-power) suggests that for correlational analyses 120 participants would give 80% power to detect an effect size of 0.22 at p<0.05.

registration_responses.q8.question: This is an intervention study where the efficacy of two CBM protocols (attentional bias retraining and response inhibition training) are compared to an active control condition (working memory task).
registration_responses.q12.question:
Inclusion Criteria:
Inclusion criteria will be a primary diagnosis of AUD and referral from clinicians. Exclusion criteria will be non-native speakers of English, diagnosis of Korsakoff syndrome, serious neurological problems including repeated seizures, learning difficulties, history of schizophrenia, strong withdrawal symptoms and visual or motor handicaps. Clinicians will assess inclusion/exclusion criteria and only those who meet criteria will be informed about the study. At the baseline session, we have also included questions on the aforementioned inclusion/exclusion criteria in the demographic questionnaire.

Proposed intervention:

1.	Information and informed consent: Individuals seeking treatment at various inpatient and outpatient faculties in NSW with a primary diagnosis of alcohol use disorder who meet inclusion criteria for the study will be informed of the study within the first three weeks of intake by a Research Psychologist/Research Assistant who is independent of their clinical care and, if interested, will be provided with information about the study. After 24 hours, if they are interested in participating, they can make an appointment with the researcher who will answer any questions. Informed consent will be obtained. Clinicians will remain blind as to the randomisation of participants. 

2.	Baseline Session: During the baseline session (1 hour long), participants will perform a general attentional bias task (15 minutes; see details below), the assessment versions of the alcohol attentional bias and alcohol response inhibition tasks (10 minutes each; see details below), as well as various self-report measures: 1. Demographic questionnaire, 2. Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test (AUDIT), 3. Severity of Alcohol Dependence Questionnaire (SADQ) 4. Obsessive Compulsive Drinking Scale (OCDS). 5. Beck Depression Inventory II (BDI). All questionnaires are attached. The baseline session will take place in a quiet room, using a laptop. Dr Poppy Watson will conduct the baseline sessions with the assistance of a research assistant and honours student (yet to be recruited and trained by Dr Poppy Watson). The experimenter will pencil in the appointments for the next six retraining sessions although flexibility will be maintained such that clients can complete the sessions at times convenient to them. Participants will receive $20 cash at the end of the baseline session as reimbursement for their time.

4.	Six x CBM retraining sessions: Over the course of 2 weeks, participants will return to the clinic (or UNSW) to complete six sessions (max. 20 minutes each) in which they complete either the alcohol attentional bias retraining task, the alcohol response inhibition task, or the working memory task (depending on the intervention group they have been assigned to). Sessions will take place in a quiet room, using a laptop. Dr Poppy Watson will conduct the retraining sessions with the assistance of a research assistant and honours student (yet to be recruited). The research assistant and student will be trained by the lead investigator (Dr Poppy Watson). Participants will receive $10 cash at the end of each session as reimbursement for their time. Treatment as usual will continue.

5.	3-month follow up: 3 months after completion of the training sessions all patients will be contacted via email and asked to complete a short questionnaire (online) assessing their alcohol use. They will also be asked to complete the OCDS questionnaire. Those who do not respond will be contacted via telephone and asked to complete the questionnaires over the phone by a researcher who is naive as to the purpose of the questionnaires (i.e. the fact that they are outcome measures following a CBM intervention). All questionnaires are attached. Upon completion of the questionnaire, the bonus payments (performance-contingent reward earned during the course of the study for all participants regardless of the condition they are assigned to) will be released to participants in the form of Woolworths or Coles vouchers. 

6.	Follow-up with clinicians: Clinic staff and clinicians who have provided treatment-as-usual alongside the CBM intervention study will be asked to indicate their views on how disruptive the study was to business as usual and suggestions for improvements in future implementation.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Over the course of 2 weeks, alongside treatment-as-usual, participants will complete six sessions (max. 20 minutes each) in which they complete either the alcohol attentional bias retraining task, the alcohol response inhibition task, or the working memory task (depending on the intervention group they have been assigned to). 

•	Alcohol Attentional Bias Task: We will use a commonly-used attentional bias task during both the baseline and retraining sessions (the dot-probe task). On each trial participants will see two images appear on either side of a computer screen – one soft drink and one alcohol image. After 500ms the pictures disappear and a small square (the target) will appear at one of the picture locations. Participants must respond to the location of the target (left or right) by pushing the appropriate arrow-key on a computer keyboard. The dependent variable is the time taken to identify the probe location. In the assessment version of this task, the target appears equally often at the location of the alcohol or soft drink image: an ‘alcohol attentional bias’ (AAB) is observed if participants are faster to respond when the target appears in the location of the alcohol picture (with a greater difference in response time indicating a greater bias). AAB score will be assessed in this way at baseline. In the re-training version of the task (used in the six treatment sessions), the target will always appear at the location of the soft drink image. In this way, participants are repeatedly trained to shift their attention away from the alcohol image and instead look at the soft drink. They will receive points for fast/accurate responses - later translated into a financial bonus (totalling between $30 and $50 overall – around $5-$8 per session) - providing additional motivation to attend to the soft-drink image rather than the alcohol image. 

•	Alcohol Response Inhibition Task: We will use a commonly-used response inhibition task (the alcohol go/no go task) during both the baseline and retraining sessions. On each trial, participants will see an image (either a soft drink or an alcohol image) appear on a computer screen. An overlaid letter will indicate whether participants should push the spacebar as quickly as possible (‘F’, 2/3 of trials) or whether they should not push any keys (‘P’, the stop signal: 1/3 of trials). The dependent variable is the proportion of stop trials where the participant is unable to inhibit their response. In the assessment version of the task, the ability to inhibit responses will be compared when the stop signal appears on the alcohol relative to the soft drink image (measured at baseline). In the re-training version of this task (used in the six treatment sessions), the stop signal will always appear on an alcohol image. In this way, participants are repeatedly trained to inhibit responding directed towards alcohol. They will also receive points for responding quickly (but stopping accurately), which will later be translated into a financial bonus (totalling between $30 and $50 overall). 

•	Active control: Working Memory Task: Participants will compete a simple working memory training task (N-back task). During this task, participants are presented with a series of alcohol and soft-drink images. In the simplest form, their task is to indicate (with a key press) if the same image is presented sequentially (1-back). Once participants have mastered 1-back (two consecutive blocks with 95% accuracy), the task is made harder by moving up a level to 2-back. Here participants must indicate whether the image on the screen is the same as that presented two images ago. This task can be made gradually harder (3-back, 4-back etc.) as accuracy improves. Participants will earn points for fast and accurate responses which will later be translated into a financial bonus (totalling between $30 and $50 overall).
registration_responses.q17.question:
Baseline Variables:

1. General Attentional Bias Task: We will use a visual search task, commonly used in our lab, to investigate distraction by general (non-alcohol-related) reward stimuli in this clinical population (baseline session only). In this task participants are instructed to find and respond to a diamond shape (the target) among a set of circles as quickly as possible, by pressing ‘C’ (horizontal) or ‘M’ (vertical). The faster participants make a correct response, the more points (and money) they earn. One of the circles in the display (the distractor) may be coloured either blue or orange (all other shapes are grey). The colour of this distractor circle indicates whether the current trial is a high- or low-reward trial. On trials with a low-reward distractor, correct responses earn 1 point for every 10 ms that respone time (RT) is below 1000 ms (e.g., an RT of 650 ms would earn 35 points). Trials with a high-reward distractor are labelled as “bonus trials”, and points are multiplied by 10 (e.g., RT of 650 ms would earn 350 points). The value-modulated attentional capture (VMAC) score is the response time to correctly identify the target when the display contains a high-reward distractor relative to when it contains a low-reward distractor.

2. Alcohol attentional bias score (see details above; RT to identify the probe on alcohol congruent relative to alcohol incongruent trials).

3. Response inhibition score (see details above; number of failed inhibitions to the stop signal on alcohol stop relative to soft-drink stop trials).
 
4. Demographic questionnaire (see attachment).
5. Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test (AUDIT). The 10-item AUDIT focuses on the negative personal outcomes attributable to alcohol use. This is the most widely used screening tool to assess hazardous and risky alcohol use behaviour with good test-retest reliability and internal validity.
6. Severity of Alcohol Dependence Questionnaire (SADQ). The 20-item SADQ captures the severity of the dependence (specifically the physical and affective symptoms of withdrawal). The measure has good construct validity and high test-retest reliability.
7. Obsessive Compulsive Drinking Scale (OCDS). This 14-item OCDS measure obsessive thoughts about alcohol use and compulsive behaviours toward drinking. The OCDS has good internal consistency and is predictive of future drinking . 
8. Beck Depression Inventory II (BDI). The BDI has proved internally consistent and acceptably reliable over an extended test-retest period.

3-month follow up variables (see attachment): 
•	Follow-up questionnaire assessing alcohol use.
•	OCDS (as above).

attributes.title: The Combined Effects of Affect and Justification on Eating in a Laboratory Based Setting

q1.value: The Combined Effects of Affect and Justification on Eating in a Laboratory Based Setting

q3.value: There is evidence that negative affect impacts various areas of emotional and cognitive functioning and decision making. There is also evidence that self-control failure can be prompted by engaging in justification-type thinking (i.e. “I deserve a treat”). We will examine the interaction of both constructs in the context of inhibitory self-control within a laboratory setting. To do this, we will manipulate the mood of participants as well as prompt for justification thinking to look for differences in amount of food consumed by condition in a laboratory food-rating task.

q4.value: We predict an interaction between mood and justification, where the largest amount of food consumption will occur for participants who both watched the negative video and who saw the poster with a justification-priming message (“I Deserve It”). We would also predict a main of effect of negative mood on greater amounts of food consumption (regardless of the presence of the justification poster) and a main effect of justification thinking on greater food consumption (regardless of mood).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: We have a between subjects design with two factors (affect and justification thinking) each with two levels (negative affect vs. neutral affect; justification thinking vs. no justification).

q9.value: Randomization procedures were performed using Excel prior to the beginning of the study. Each participant number was randomly assigned to either “negative” or “neutral” affect conditions and either “justification” or “no justification” poster conditions where we attempted to have approximately equal numbers of participants.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Collection of data has begun and is currently ongoing. To date there has been no tabulation or analysis of any data.

question.value: Participants are being recruited through the University of Arkansas undergraduate subject pool. Participants are awarded research credit in exchange for their participation in the study.

q13.value: We seek to recruit at least 200 participants for this study (50 per cell).

q15.value: Data collection will continue until at least 200 participants have completed the study, however, if there is an opportunity to continue running participants during the Spring 2020 semester, we will continue to collect data until the end of the semester.

question.value: We will manipulate the mood of participants; half of participants will view a video intended to induce negative mood, while the other half will view a neutral video. We will also manipulate the presence of justification thinking using a poster in the lab. Half of participants will see a poster on the wall of the lab that primes for justification thinking (“I Deserve It”), while the other half will view a poster of the same photo without the text. Participants will be told the study is one examining the effect of films on taste perception and preferences.

We will measure the participants’ pre- and post-film ratings of positive mood, negative mood, hunger, and craving to assess any changes. Participants will also complete validated measures of self-control (Brief Self-Control Scale), emotional reactivity (Emotional Reactivity Scale), and restrained eating behavior (Restrained Eating Scale). We will also measure how much the participant eats during the study by weighing the food before and after the tasting period. Additionally, to support the cover story of the study, we will collect participant ratings of the foods. Finally, we will also measure justification thinking in the context of deservingness, compensatory behaviors, and irresistibility subscales adapted from a justification measure (Taylor, Webb, & Sheeran, 2014). Items are measured on a Likert-type scale from 1 (never) to 5 (always).
We will average the deservingness, compensatory behaviors, and irresistibility items into three separate measures.

We will use a factorial ANOVA to examine the effect of affect (negative vs. neutral) and justification (justification poster vs. no justification) condition on the amount of food eaten. To determine the efficacy of the mood manipulation, we will conduct a 2 (mood; pre-post within subjects) by 2 (affect; negative vs. neutral) by 2 (justification vs. no justification) mixed ANOVA to examine changes in affect from pre- to post-video. We will also correlate levels of justification thinking with amount of food eaten. Additionally, we will conduct 2 x 2 ANOVAs looking at the influence of affect condition and justification condition on levels of justification thinking (deservingness, compensatory behaviors, and irresistibility subscales).  Finally, we will use a factorial ANOVA to examine how affect condition and justification condition impact participant ratings of the food.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if results suggest that the groups are significantly different than expected if the null hypothesis were true.

q22.value: We will exclude participants who do not complete the entirety of the study procedures and those who fail manipulation check questions on study procedures (“What was the topic of the video you watched?”; “Did you notice the poster on the wall during the study?”).

q24.value: We will examine potential moderators of the effect of mood and justification on amount eaten, namely trait self-control, emotional reactivity, and reported levels of restrained eating behavior. We will also examine any significant findings within the compensatory behaviors and irresistibility subscales of the justification measure. Finally, we will examine how time of day that participants completed the study (Morning [8:00AM – 11:00AM], Midday [11:00AM – 2:00PM], or Afternoon [2:00PM – 5:00PM]) impacts the amount of food eaten.

attributes.title: Sequence effects and speech perception: Cognitive load for speaker-switching within and across accents

q1.value: Sequence effects and speech perception: Cognitive load for speaker-switching within and across accents

q2.value: Drew Jordan McLaughlin, Jackson Colvett, Julie Bugg, Kristin Van Engen

q3.value:
Listening to unfamiliar, nonnative- (i.e., foreign) accented speech can be more effortful than listening to familiar, native-accented speech, even when second language speakers are highly proficient (McLaughlin & Van Engen, under review; Brown et al., under review). In this study, we will examine how switching between native and nonnative speakers increases cognitive processing load (or “listening effort”), and conversely how the load associated with nonnative speech may be reduced after having recently listened to a nonnative speaker.

Examining load as a function of the speaker accent on not only the current trial (native vs. nonnative) but also the preceding trial (native vs. nonnative) is relatively novel in the speech perception literature. However, it is common to examine such sequence effects in the cognitive control literature as a means of exploring how processing adjustments that occur on trial n – 1 may affect performance on trial n. Congruency sequence effects (CSEs) refer to the finding that participants have a reduced congruency effect (i.e., the difference between congruent and incongruent trial performance) following an incongruent trial compared to a congruent trial (e.g., Egner, 2007). Though it has been debated whether these effects are driven by an abstract cognitive control mechanism or lower level factors (feature repetition; contingency), there exist designs that isolate cognitive control and demonstrate that conflict on the previous trial affects how one attends to goal-relevant information on the next trial (see e.g., Braem et al., 2019) . Inspired by this evidence, we examined whether sequence effects would also be observed in the context of speech perception; that is, does your immediately preceding listening experience affect your current listening performance? 

The aim of this study is to investigate whether switching between speakers increases cognitive load during speech perception, as measured by pupil diameter. Specifically, we will test whether pupil response is greater when switching speakers within a given accent (both native 1 to native 2, and nonnative 1 to nonnative 2), and switching speakers across accents. In each case, we will compare against pupil response when listening to the same speaker (i.e., repeats). It should be noted that an alternative interpretation of this relationship would be that listening to the same speaker as on a previous trial provides a benefit (i.e., reduced cognitive load).  

Further, we aim to replicate evidence demonstrating that processing accurately-recognized nonnative-accented speech is more cognitively demanding than processing speech produced by a native-accented talker (McLaughlin & Van Engen, under review; Brown et al., under review). The design of this experiment will extend previous findings by examining this effect with multiple speakers per accent.

q4.value:
There will be two native speakers (native 1 and native 2) and two nonnative speakers (nonnative 1 and nonnative 2). There will be six conditions of interest for the analysis with condition being determined by the speaker on the current trial and the previous trial: native repeat (e.g., native 1, native 1), nonnative repeat (e.g., nonnative 1, nonnative 1), within-native switch (e.g., native 1, native 2), within-nonnative switch (e.g., nonnative 1, nonnative 2), native-to-nonnative switch (e.g., native 1, nonnative 1), and nonnative-to-native switch (e.g., nonnative 1, native 1). 

We predict the following:
1)	Pupil response will be greater (indicating greater cognitive load) when switching speakers than when listening to the same speaker.
a)	Specifically: 
i)	within-native switch > native repeat
ii)	within-nonnative switch > nonnative repeat
iii)	nonnative-to-native switch > native repeat
iv)	native-to-nonnative switch > nonnative repeat
2)	Pupil response will be greater when switching across accents than switching speakers within a given accent.
a)	Specifically:
i)	nonnative-to-native switch > within-native switch
ii)	native-to-nonnative switch > within-nonnative switch
3)	There will be an interaction between accent on the current trial and accent on the previous trial, such that the difference between native-to-nonnative switch and nonnative repeat is greater than the difference between nonnative-to-native switch and native repeat.
a)	That is, switching between accents will come at a greater cognitive cost for nonnative-accented speech.
4)	There will be a main effect of accent type (nonnative > native) when collapsing across conditions and speakers (replicating McLaughlin & Van Engen, under review, and Brown et al., under review).
a)	We may also test whether there are any differences in pupil response for the speakers within each accent (this would be exploratory).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: There is no random assignment in this study. However, when scoring recognition accuracy, the condition of each trial will be hidden from the scorer.

question.value: The study will have a repeated measures design. There will be four pseudo-randomized lists specifying the order of condition presentation. This will ensure an equal number of trials per condition. Sentence targets will be presented in a random order within this structure. The combination of speaker and sentence targets will be counterbalanced, such that some participants may hear a given target (e.g., “the gray mouse ate the cheese”) read by nonnative speaker 1, some others may hear it read by native speaker 2, and so on.

q9.value: Sentence targets will be presented in a random order (see response above).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
This study will examine young adult subjects recruited from the Washington University Psychology Subject Pool. Participants will receive course credit in exchange for participation. We plan to collect data during 2020.

Participants will be excluded from analyses if they are not a native speaker of English, have abnormal hearing or vision (corrected-to-normal vision will be acceptable), personally speak with a Mandarin accent, or report having substantial previous exposure to Mandarin-accented English (i.e., have roommates, parents, or close family members who speak with a Mandarin accent, or have taken Mandarin in a classroom setting).

q13.value: We will collect data from 50 subjects, and replace any subjects that are excluded for data loss or failure to meet eligibility criteria. There will be 16 trials per condition for each subject.

q14.value: Sample size was selected based on sufficient power to examine similar effects in an existing dataset (McLaughlin & Van Engen, under review).

question.value: In the listening task, we will measure pupil diameter and recognition accuracy. Using questionnaires, we will ascertain demographic and language background information about each participant.

Growth curve analysis will be used to analyze the pupil data. Some of the model specifications will depend on the shape of the pupil response. If the shape is cubic, only polynomials up to the cubic term will be included, if quadratic, only polynomials up to the quadratic term, and so on, as determined by hierarchical model comparisons. In all of the full models, random effects will include subject on the intercept and each polynomial time term (as in Mirman, 2014), item on the intercept and each polynomial time term. 

We will use five models to investigate our predictions. Model 1 will include all of the experiment data and the following fixed effects: accent (ordered levels: native and nonnative), switch (ordered levels: no switch, switch within accent, and switch across accent), and the interaction between accent and switch. Model 1 will primarily address hypotheses 3 and 4.

Models 2 and 3 will include experiment data from the native and nonnative conditions, respectively. The fixed effect will be the same in both models: switch (ordered levels: no switch, switch within accent, and switch across accent). Models 2 and 3 allow us to directly test predictions of hypothesis 1.

Models 4 and 5 will include experiment data only from conditions in which there was a speaker switch (within-native switch, within-nonnative switch, native-to-nonnative switch, and nonnative-to-native switch), examining the accent conditions separately. The fixed effects will be the same in both models: switch (ordered levels: switch within accent, and switch across accent). Models 4 and 5 allow us to directly test predictions of hypothesis 2.

q21.value: A significance threshold of p < .05 will be applied.

q22.value:
Trials for which the participant does not repeat back the target sentence correctly (that is, gets fewer than 4/4 keywords correct), will be excluded from analyses. 

Trials will be excluded if more than 20% of the pupil data is coded as a blink, and participants with more than 20% trial loss will be excluded from analyses entirely and replaced.

q23.value: Growth curve analysis is robust against missing data, so we do not expect this to be an issue.

q24.value: We may also test whether there are any differences in pupil response for the speakers within each accent (this would require separate modeling).

q25.value: Pre-processing of the pupil data will be done in R using the gazeR package and following steps recommended by Geller and colleagues (under review). First, trials with more than 20% data loss due to blinks and participants with more than 25% trial loss in any condition will be excluded. Periods of missing data will be identified as blinks and extended 100 ms prior and 200 ms following (to remove noise due to moving eyelids). Linear interpolation will be used to fill in the missing data. Next, a five-point moving average will smooth the data. Each trial will be baselined by subtracting the median value of the 500 ms immediately preceding the beginning of the stimulus from all values. Lastly, the data will be time-binned, reducing the sampling frequency from 500 Hz to 50 Hz.

registration_responses.q1: Sequence effects and speech perception: Cognitive load for speaker-switching within and across accents
registration_responses.q2: Drew Jordan McLaughlin, Jackson Colvett, Julie Bugg, Kristin Van Engen
registration_responses.q3:
Listening to unfamiliar, nonnative- (i.e., foreign) accented speech can be more effortful than listening to familiar, native-accented speech, even when second language speakers are highly proficient (McLaughlin & Van Engen, under review; Brown et al., under review). In this study, we will examine how switching between native and nonnative speakers increases cognitive processing load (or “listening effort”), and conversely how the load associated with nonnative speech may be reduced after having recently listened to a nonnative speaker.

Examining load as a function of the speaker accent on not only the current trial (native vs. nonnative) but also the preceding trial (native vs. nonnative) is relatively novel in the speech perception literature. However, it is common to examine such sequence effects in the cognitive control literature as a means of exploring how processing adjustments that occur on trial n – 1 may affect performance on trial n. Congruency sequence effects (CSEs) refer to the finding that participants have a reduced congruency effect (i.e., the difference between congruent and incongruent trial performance) following an incongruent trial compared to a congruent trial (e.g., Egner, 2007). Though it has been debated whether these effects are driven by an abstract cognitive control mechanism or lower level factors (feature repetition; contingency), there exist designs that isolate cognitive control and demonstrate that conflict on the previous trial affects how one attends to goal-relevant information on the next trial (see e.g., Braem et al., 2019) . Inspired by this evidence, we examined whether sequence effects would also be observed in the context of speech perception; that is, does your immediately preceding listening experience affect your current listening performance? 

The aim of this study is to investigate whether switching between speakers increases cognitive load during speech perception, as measured by pupil diameter. Specifically, we will test whether pupil response is greater when switching speakers within a given accent (both native 1 to native 2, and nonnative 1 to nonnative 2), and switching speakers across accents. In each case, we will compare against pupil response when listening to the same speaker (i.e., repeats). It should be noted that an alternative interpretation of this relationship would be that listening to the same speaker as on a previous trial provides a benefit (i.e., reduced cognitive load).  

Further, we aim to replicate evidence demonstrating that processing accurately-recognized nonnative-accented speech is more cognitively demanding than processing speech produced by a native-accented talker (McLaughlin & Van Engen, under review; Brown et al., under review). The design of this experiment will extend previous findings by examining this effect with multiple speakers per accent.

a)	We may also test whether there are any differences in pupil response for the speakers within each accent (this would be exploratory).

attributes.title: Development of an Intervention to Promote Agentic Engagement in STEM High School Classrooms

q1.value: Development of an Intervention to Promote Agentic Engagement in STEM High School Classrooms

q3.value: This investigation explores the effects of an intervention intended to promote a mindset and strategies for agentic engagement among high school physical science students. Engaging students in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) classes remains a critical challenge. The challenge is particularly great at the high school level, as students’ engagement in STEM decline across grades, and for female, black, and Hispanic/Latino students, who remain underrepresented in STEM college majors and careers, particular physical science majors and careers. Thus, the purpose of the current investigation is to develop an intervention to enhance students’ agentic engagement in physical science class and test its potential benefits for high school students’ motivation, engagement, perceptions of the classroom environment, and achievement, particularly among students traditionally underrepresented in STEM. The intervention will then be pilot tested with urban high school science students and teachers in a randomized controlled design. Data will be analyzed with multilevel modeling.

q4.value:
Promoting an agentic engagement orientation (i.e., training students to adopt a malleable mindset of physical science motivation and the motivational qualities of the physical science classroom environment and use a variety of agentic engagement strategies) will lead to a greater agentic engagement mindset and strategy use in physical science classes compared to students in a control group who received information about study strategies.

Relative to a study skills control group, the agentic engagement intervention will lead to benefits for high school students’ in-class engagement (e.g., behavioral, cognitive, emotional), motivation (e.g., need satisfaction, autonomous motivation, personal interest), academic achievement (e.g., course grades), and intentions to persist in physical science (e.g., course enrollment, career intentions) via an agentic engagement mindset and strategies.

Relative to the study skills control condition, the agentic engagement intervention will lead to greater student perceived, teacher reported, and observed teacher motivation (autonomy) support and less teacher control among intervention classes compared to control classes via an agentic engagement mindset and strategies.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Two-group, cluster-randomized, with repeated measures (3 measurement time points).
Randomization occurs at the teacher level (with multiple class sections and students within each teacher).

q9.value: Simple randomization at the teacher level. Lower levels include class sections and students.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Sample: Urban high school teachers and students from Los Angeles, CA (any grade). Public and charter schools. 10 teachers and their students who consent from 33 classes. Teachers were invited to pilot study because they previously participated in focus groups to develop intervention. All students in teachers' classes have equal opportunity to participate and be included in analyses. Recruitment efforts included announcements in classes. Students receive $5 to return consent forms and $5 per complete part of the study. Data collection consists of three in-class sessions to adminster the intervention program (visit 1 and 2) and collect baseline and post-intervention data (visit 1, 2, and 3). Data collection session 1 occurs in late January-Feb 2020 (starting Jan. 21 2020), data collection session 2 occurs in March 2020, data collection session 3 occurs in mid April to early May 2020.

q14.value: This is a pilot test of a new intervention. Rationale for sample was not based on statistical power. Sample size represents a small sample, given that the intervention is cluster randomized. However, large enough to give a sense of how the intervention is working. Limited funds to collect additional data.

q15.value: Data collection will end summer 2020, regardless of sample size.

question.value:
One manipulated variable: Exposure to an agentic engagement intervention versus comparison. 
Two conditions:
1. Agentic engagement intervention
2. Study skills intervention

Outcomes:
Agentic engagement mindset
Agentic engagement (strategies)
Agentic disengagement
Behavioral engagement
Emotional engagement
Cognitive engagement
Behavioral disengagement
Emotional disengagement
Cognitive disengagement
Need satisfaction
Need frustration
Utility value
Attainment value
Intrinsic value
Student perceptions of teacher autonomy support
Student perceptions of teacher control
Observations of teacher autonomy support
Observations of teacher control
Teacher report of autonomy support
Teacher report of control
Observations of student engagement
Course grade
Science learning intentions
Science course intentions
Science major intentions
Science career intentions

Covariates:
Gender
Race
Student racial stigma
Teacher agentic mindset
Teacher science ability mindset
Teacher motivating style

Exploratory factor analyses will be used to assess structure of newly developed scales (agentic engagement mindset).
Reliability will be assessed for previously validated scales.
Several single item outcomes are of interest (course grade, intentions to take more science courses).

We will begin analyses by determining the reliability of self-report and observation scales. Analyses will be conducted within a framework of multiple-group multilevel confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) using the MLR estimator in Mplus 8 (Muthén & Muthén, 2017). 

Hierarchical linear modeling (HLM; Raudenbush & Bryk, 2002) will be used to address research questions. Such modeling appropriately addresses the nested design of the data, in which lower level units (reports) are nested within higher level units (students within classes, within teachers).  Given that teachers are also nested within schools, but a small number of them (5 schools), these models will also adjust standard errors and chi-square tests of model fit for this clustering by school (with the TYPE=COMPLEX command available in Mplus software). 

To address the first hypothesis and examine the extent to which the intervention increases students’ agentic engagement mindsets and strategy use relative to a comparison condition, we will conduct four-level regression models in which intervention condition, time, and their interaction are the primary predictors of students’ agentic engagement beliefs and behavior. This analysis allows us to examine change over time as a function of the intervention. We will follow-up this analysis with a three-level regression model to examine the effect of intervention at each post-intervention time point, controlling for baseline outcome values. 

The second and third hypothesis will be addressed similarly in a series of four- and three- level regression models for each of student reported motivation, engagement, achievement, science intention, and classroom perception outcomes. Agentic engagement mindsets and strategy use will be subsequently added as predictors to these models to test indirect effects of the intervention via agentic engagement mindset and agentic engagement strategies, with such indirect effects estimated and tested using the Monte Carlo Method for Assessing Mediation (MCMAM; Bauer, Preacher, & Gil, 2006; MacKinnon, Lockwood, & Williams, 2004; Selig & Preacher, 2008). 

The similar strategy will be used for observation outcomes occurring at the classroom level (e.g., teachers’ observed autonomy support and control) and teacher reports of support and control (reported at teacher level across all classes). In the case of observation outcomes, aggregates across the three post-intervention videos will be computed (to enhance reliability) and two-level regressions will be conducted with the intervention as a predictor. Observed student engagement will be subsequently added as a predictor to these models to test indirect effects of the intervention via observed student engagement. For teacher reports of autonomy support and control, single-level regressions with intervention as the predictor and student engagement (aggregated from the class to teacher level) will be conducted.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining significance in two-tailed tests. This is a pilot test -- no adjustments for multiple tests.

q22.value:
Participants who do not complete all aspects of intervention (view all slides) will be excluded from analysis. Participants who complete only intervention session and do not complete either follow-up session (of 2) in which outcomes are measured will be excluded from analysis. 

For all covariates and outcomes, outliers (values + or - 3 standard deviations of the mean) will be initially included in analyses. Sensitivity analyses will be conducted to assess if results change after excluding outliers.

q23.value: Will will use maximum likelihood estimation in multilevel models.

attributes.title: The Affiliative Consequences of Same-Race and Cross-Race Mimicry
attributes.description: Posted are the experimental materials and data for the paper "The Affiliative Consequences of Same-Race and Cross-Race Mimicry" (Journal of Social Psychology) with the following abstract: Few studies have replicated and extended the classic mimicry to liking effect. The present research sought to (a) replicate the affiliative consequences of mimicry; (b) test whether the affiliative consequences hold in a context where mimicry may not be normative (i.e., cross-race interactions); and (c) investigate how excluded individuals respond to same- versus cross-race mimicry and non-mimicry. Participants wrote about a control topic or social exclusion and then engaged in a brief laboratory interaction in which they were mimicked or not mimicked by a confederate who was either same-race or cross-race. Then they reported how much they liked the confederate. Within the control condition, the effect of mimicry on affiliation depended on the race of the confederate—but this pattern did not emerge for excluded individuals. The study was unable to conclusively replicate and extend previous findings. The authors make recommendations to promote a more cumulative science of behavioral mimicry.

attributes.title: Production Effect and False Memory (Within Subjects)

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: With the program G*Power 3.1, we performed a power analysis to calculate the sample size. Based on our previous data in related work, we estimated a Cohen's d of 0.34 for the critical t-test of interest (production's effect on false recognition). According to the power analysis, a sample size of at least 70 participants is required to achieve .80 power. Thus, we plan to test 80 participants.

analyses.value:
We will use 2x2 within-subjects ANOVA (word type: studied vs critical lure, production: aloud vs silent) on recognition rates. We will follow up with paired samples t-test to compare the false recognition rates as well as true recognition rates in the two conditions. 

We will also use 2x2x2 within-subjects ANOVA (word type: studied vs critical lure, production: aloud vs silent, response: remember vs know) on proportion of remember/know responses. We will follow up with paired t-tests.

outliers.value:
We will exclude participants who did not follow instructions during the experiment. Also, participants whose mean recognition of the studied items is worse than 2 standard deviations below the mean will also be excluded.
Excluded participants will be replaced.

conditions.value: The experiment is a within-subject design with two conditions: the aloud condition and the silent condition. Participants will view words (a random half presented in red and the other half in blue), and read words presented in one color aloud and words in the other color silently (counterbalanced).

hypothesis.value: Will producing items aloud (i.e., reading words aloud) influence false memory rates compared to reading words silently (i.e., more normal encoding)?

attributes.title: Replication of the trend effect
attributes.description: In this study I will test to what extent previous findings on the trend effect of Hohle & Teigen (2015) will recur.

item1.value: Expert forecasts that are being revised are perceived as a trend. Just two expert forecasts are enough to define such a trend, on the basis of which non-experts make further assessments (instead of referring to the last and thus most accurate expert forecast).

item2.value: Previous studies mainly focus on forecasts in the climate context, although the implications for the communication of forecasts go beyond this. It is therefore useful to examine the effect in a different context.

item8.value: Students (introductory course in educational sciences, University of Oslo)

item11.value: The texts of my questionnaire are closely based on the texts of the original study

item13.value: Has knowledge about the experimental conditions

item16.value: An a priori power analysis was performed

item24.value:
The replication study is being performed in another country.
The questionnaire texts were modified (translated into German; cover other subjects).
The examination of the effect ist based on other subjects (population and economic growth instead of climate phenomena).
The framework conditions of the original study were only briefly described, it is only possible to speculate whether they are identical.

item25.value:
The authors were contacted and asked for the original materials. 
The questionnaire texts were retranslated. 
Additional questions determine the role of previous beliefs in the new subjects.

item26.value:
Removal of a participant:
If no response was given to either scenario.

Removal of an answer:
If the answer format does not correspond to a semantically correct solution (e.g. answer by a drawing).
If it can be assumed that a participant did not understand the task correctly or deliberately falsified the result. This is the case if numerical answers are outside a logically comprehensible frame.
- This concerns the years 2015 / 2025 / 2100
- For the birth rate, this applies to values > 100,000
- For GDP, this applies to values < 40% and > 100%

item27.value:
Report of the gender distribution and the average age of the participants as well as the direction of the estimates for both scenarios.

Comparison of the mean values of the estimates of the two trends per scenario and testing of significance (using a two-factor ANOVA, as in the original paper, is not possible because the variable "order" was not included in the survey).

Comparison of the mean values of previous beliefs for the two trends. Correlation between the mean of the previous beliefs for each scenario and the results of the estimates (the comparison of beliefs with a national sample is not possible).

item28.value: A significant difference in the mean values of the trends in both scenarios confirming the trend effect
